Please Note: Co-op students are not liable for tuition fee charges for this course. As a key part of their planning degree, students must undertake 48 weeks of approved employment related to the professional objectives of the Planning and Urban Development Program: for example, in private development companies, planning consultancies, state government departments and agencies, or with local councils. This is normally undertaken in the twelve months following the end of Session 1 of Year 3. The Program Head must approve the type of employment proposed. The requirements of courses PLAN0081 and PLAN0082 Work Experience must be successfully completed before a student will be permitted to graduate. Assessment components include documentation and submission of a work experience diary, a reflective report and participation in a compulsory seminar.

This course introduces students commencing their planning studies to the principles which underlie planning as both a discipline and practice, and provide a foundation to the methods and frameworks planners use to achieve their objectives and goals. The course explores the role of different organisations and stakeholders involved in the planning process, and the crucial interplay between planning and urban development. An integral element of the course is a field trip out of Sydney where introductory planning concepts, ideas and issues can be explored in practice. This will involve a series of projects and contributions from practising planners sharing their insights in context.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e4f361ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

The final exam will be 60 multiple choice questions and short-answer based on assigned readings, Lectures given throughout the semester, and the fieldtrip.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"14f361ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"50f361ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9cf361ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e8f361ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"08f361ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Each group of 3 students is required to prepare a 1500-word report on an area within the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Please select one of the ten Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Statistical Area 3 in the Australian Capital Territory areas for investigation.     

The report should include:

  • A description of the community by identifying key demographics
  • A description of employment and business activity;
  • A snapshot of urban infrastructure (transport, green space, community facilities, cultural infrastructure, etc);
  • Analysis of how/whether the urban infrastructure supports local community needs.
  • Analysis of transport links between your selected SA3 area and other parts of Canberra.
  • Identification of potential urban interventions that may help urban infrastructure better meet community needs.

*details of this assessment can be found on Moodle under Resources.

based on lectures, assigned texts, and anything in the course outline: There will be approximately 30 multiple choice questions on the test covering weeks 1-4. It is completed in-class at the start of class; therefore, you must be in class to receive one. The test will end at 12 and the lecture will begin promptly thereafter.

This course examines the interrelationships between urbanisation, planning and the sustainable management of environmental systems. It introduces the role of environmental processes in shaping the patterns of the physical environment and the operation of global environmental systems, with a focus on interaction of humans with their environment and the causes of environmental crises. The role of environmental factors and their centrality to complex and typically contested planning issues including population growth, resource extraction, biodiversity, and food and water security is considered. The course reviews principles of ecologically sustainable development and encourages students to consider how issues are framed, how solutions are negotiated and question whether current planning frameworks help or hinder broader sustainability objectives. Students are introduced to key concepts associated with ‘sustainable urbanism’ including low carbon development, green infrastructure, climate change adaptation and mitigation. Analytical and procedural tools for use in strategic and tactical management of the urban environment and non-metropolitan regions impacted by urbanisation are introduced.

This course is an overview of planning studies through the frameworks of history, and urban planning theory. This is applied to modern planning practice, and the development of urban planning as a distinct profession. The main topics include the different planning paradigms and theories that have influenced urban planning in Australian and world cities; city typologies, past and present ‘ideal’ models of the city; social order; and the contemporary art of city-making in changing socioeconomic, environmental and political worlds.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1eeb91bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961978","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial quizzes and tasks","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Each student is required to stand up in front of the class with one PowerPoint slide that they have created and talk for 3 minutes on an urban topic of their choice. This should be a snapshot of the topic you have researched – it is the same topic lays the groundwork for the Urban Planning Report. Global topics are welcome. Also required are: 1) two page Harvard Reference Bibliography of academic references related to the topic; 2) a one page summary of the topic.

 

This assessment task is lays the groundwork for the Urban Planning Report. Feedback will be given back to the studetn very quickly so that they can use this to build on for their Urban Report.

of readings","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

These required weekly readings are a core component of Urban Society and must be handed in at the beginning of the class in which they are due. Submit a one typed page (maximum, one-sided, 10 point font minimum) that includes a complete Harvard referencing citation for the reading(s), a summary of the main points of the article and two well-considered questions which could be used to initiate tutorial discussions or be on a quiz.

 

These one page assignments will be marked and returned with comments by the following week.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"12eb91bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"46eb91bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bdeb91bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961928","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Urban issue – summary + bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

This report will be filled into the proforma given out in class and should be the result of your best efforts at researching, summarising and writing about an urban issue of your choice. This will be well-researched, scholarly, sourced using Harvard Referencing, well-written and present a comprehensive and deep understanding of a contemporary or historical urban issue. The proforma will include a description of the topic, problem identification; background to the problem; key theorist/s relevant to the topic and other topics on the proforma.

 

Individual feedback on the proforma will be given back to the student as early as reasonably possible.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN1004","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN1004 - City and Regional Economics","description":"

This course provides a foundation of city and regional economics with a range of key economic concepts and models to shape urban land uses, firm locations and housing and labour market systems in cities. The  course encompasses the following main areas: micro/macroeconomic processes that drive urban land use, governance and planning systems; market failures as the source of urban planning problems; development feasibility and the economic theories of urbanisation, gentrification and globalisation. In particular micro-economic and macro-economic processes underpin urban land-use patterns, property values, activity and transport systems. The processes of economic growth and decline are a perennial consideration of planning at different scales. Therefore the course focuses on development and planning across metropolitan and non-metropolitan regions. Students gain an understanding of how planning objectives are influenced by the aggregate impacts of uneven economic growth processes and economic behaviour. They gain familiarity with the potentialities and limitations of public policy in influencing spatial outcomes through studying economic issues and problems. Practical techniques for analysing spatial structure and development projects are introduced. Instruction is through lectures and tutorials.

The group presentation (Pecha Kucha) is an opportunity to apply your knowledge of key concepts, theories and ideas covered in the first six (6) weeks of term. In completing this task, you will be engaging with, and demonstrating an understanding of some or all of the following: economic concepts and models that help explain land values and the location of economic activity; concepts of supply, demand and equilibrium; the role and function of public and private sector in urban economic growth; the impact of infrastructure provision on land use and spatial structure; and an understanding of social and economic issues.

The Pecha Kucha format will require you and your group to make the complex simple – having only 20 slides of 20 seconds each to communicate your argument, or analyse your topic. The weekly deliverables will help provide a structure for the preparation of your presentation. The fact sheet is an opportunity to clearly communicate your topic for the educational benefit of your peers.

Aims: 

Provide a compelling argument / detailed analysis grounded in evidence-based research in relation to one of the topics below.

Undertaking broad research, utilising valid and reliable sources of information, making the complex simple through an engaging graphic presentation will be key to a successful presentation.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN1007","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN1007 - Development Processes: Feasibility and Finance","description":"



This course provides an introduction to the processes involved in property development in market economics in the context of government regulatory and approval processes. Students are introduced to the range of different actors and stakeholders involved in urban development of different scales, from multinational high-density residential developers to small and medium sized companies operating across different sectors and sub-markets. Topics include the nature and purposes of property development, a brief introduction to real property law, development economics, the regulatory context, and taxation issues. Emphasis is placed on understanding how developers work, how they determine the feasibility of projects and how they engage with the planning system. Students are encouraged to build up an appreciation of the challenges and issues arising from development, government and community perspectives. In exploring feasibility questions, students will develop a hypothetical site and explore feasibility options for its development within relevant planning parameters.  


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4e3d197fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96191d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Development Project Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Individually you will be required to choose a current residential development project known to you and discuss a range of matters relating to its approval, sales, commencement and construction. The assignment will be used to question the operations of the property development industry, focusing on a particular project and how various developers, authorities, or markets interact. Comprehensive research and investigation of your chosen development Project will be a major component of the assessment and a thorough understanding of the project must be clearly demonstrated in your submitted report. You are encouraged to be critical, and to consider how the intervention or advocacy of developers, market dynamics and planners may contribute to results in the development process.

The Feasibility Assessment report is an individual project which involves an assessment of an actual development site and is to be presented in the form of a consultant report prepared for a developer. Further details will be provided and discussed in Week 1.

contentlets.keywords: planning and urban development,property development,development processes,urban development,nsw planning system,property market,planning approval,feasibility analysis,market analysis
contentlets.description: This course provides an introduction to the processes involved in property development in market economics in the context of government regulatory and approval processes. Students are introduced to the range of different actors and stakeholders involved in urban development of different scales, from multinational high-density residential developers to small and medium sized companies operating across different sectors and sub-markets. Topics include the nature and purposes of property development, a brief introduction to real property law, development economics, the regulatory context, and taxation issues. Emphasis is placed on understanding how developers work, how they determine the feasibility of projects and how they engage with the planning system. Students are encouraged to build up an appreciation of the challenges and issues arising from development, government and community perspectives. In exploring feasibility questions, students will develop a hypothetical site and explore feasibility options for its development within relevant planning parameters.
contentlets.title: Development Processes: Feasibility and Finance

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN2001","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN2001 - Strategic Planning","description":"

Strategic planning is a dynamic, analytical, and interdisciplinary process, and in its academic context is where the practical, applied nature of the discipline is interrogated through a more conceptual, theoretical and critical lens. A major characteristic is the synthesis of diverse information and analysis, alongside community and stakeholder opinion into communicable planning documents. This course provides instruction in the theory and practice of strategic planning as an integrative activity and adopts an applied focus in considering a contemporary multifaceted planning issue. The key drivers of change within our cities, for example housing supply and affordability, urban renewal, urban justice, infrastructure and transport, are unpacked, and the tensions that shape how decisions get made - or not - understood through the complex lens of urban governance and how planning - and planners - engaged with those we plan for. As planners we are interested in the inherently spatial dimensions of these urban processes, recognising that collective efforts to influence land use change and behaviours of urban stakeholders take place at different geographical scales, and impact on different groups in different ways. This course focuses on the metropolitan scale, where the conditions requiring strategic planning are arguably most evident.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN2002","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN2002 - Geographical Information Systems and Urban Informatics","description":"



This course deals with Geographical Information Systems (GIS) and their applications in urban studies, public management, and environment planning contexts. It recognises that major developments have occurred across these areas that are important for careers in government, planning, business, public works and other types of organisations. The course focuses on the principles and concepts of GIS and spatial data analysis to provide students with the conceptual and practical skills and knowledge to utilise relevant technical tools for data analysis, spatial mapping and data visualisation. The course will teach students how to access meta-databases (AURIN) and use open source GIS software. Through the learning of this software students will begin to see the connection between concepts-data-tools-visualisation. Students will develop a suitable level of proficiency in the application of the technology to an array of spatial problems. General topics include a solid understanding of the importance of spatial data and data layers, components and functions of GIS, and of types of spatial data models and databases, their entry, analysis, manipulation and display into a GIS.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e18835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619c9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e18835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e18835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e98835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e98835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ed8835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0a8835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619db","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final project report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The aim of this assessment is for students to show an understanding of the process behind GIS analysis, ability to identify the effective use of data, tools and visualisation and to use some critical thought.

This assessment mirrors the use of GIS in a real-world professional context. Students will assume the role of a project manager of a consultancy, and will assess a piece of spatial analysis undertaken by a member of their team. Students will have to assess this analysis, to identify errors, strengths and weaknesses. The purpose of this assessment is to show knowledge of core concepts in GIS, and encourage students to demonstrate their critical thinking.

Written feedback will be provided by the lecturer

 

 

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e18835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e18835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e98835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e98835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ed8835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d8835e8dbcc2090eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project inception report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The aim of this assessment is for students to familarise themselves with the diverse sources of real-world spatial data provided by the Australian Urban Research Infrastructure Network (AURIN). Students are to prepare a short report (no longer than three pages including supporting figures, tables and charts) on an application, process or project which uses spatial data from the AURIN database and demonstrate their understanding of key concepts of such data sets within the planning context.  

Students must examine one of the following AURIN topic areas/databases:

  • Demographics, Social Indicators and Economic Activity
  • Urban Design and Housing
  • Health and Quality of Life
  • Infrastructure and Transport

This assessment is designed to introduce students to the nature and application of spatial data and how it is used within the urban planning context.

 

Written feedback will be provided by the lecturer

Urban design as a field of activity is concerned with the four-dimensional form and functioning of the public realm. It is both a process and a product and is often regarded as the integrative force that straddles and connects the more traditional built environment disciplines: urban design aims to reunite the partnership between planning and design to help improve the quality and sustainability of the built environment. This course provides an introduction to urban design theory and practice. It is designed to equip students with the skills they need to appreciate and critique urban design, and to engage in the design process. Particular skills to be developed include site context analysis, computer-based design and presentation, and the formulation of robust planning and urban design controls. 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f54b193bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96191a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Urban Design Studio (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Group assessment. Students will work in small groups to propose a justifiable urban design vision for a development site in Sydney.

Each group will present its work to a panel of experts.

A component of the marks for Assessment 2 will be awarded to individuals based on their participation and contribution to the team effort.

Verbal and written feedback

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN2004","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN2004 - Equitable Cities","description":"

Equitable Cities examines contemporary issues facing planners working in a diverse and complex society. Students engage with the broader social, economic and cultural shifts which are continually reshaping the neoliberal city. Students consider questions of spatial disadvantage, social exclusion, ‘spatial justice’ and equity, and ‘rights to the city’. Change in the built environment invariably impacts on disadvantaged and disenfranchised groups disproportionately, where for example redevelopment and gentrification may be accompanied by quickly changing community profiles, rising housing costs, unhealthy environments and potential displacement. As planners we must steward the future direction of our cities and communities in ways which value and foster diversity. Planners must ensure that the interests and needs of all groups, including ethnic communities, children, the aged, women, people with disabilities, people of all sexual preferences, Indigenous and homeless people are heard. Planners are also increasingly engaged with the creation of healthy built environments, fostering wellbeing alongside health professionals in decisions taken which affect the built environment's ability to be supportive of healthy behaviour. The role and capacity of current planning frameworks to achieve more equitable and health supportive outcomes are explored, including the preparation of community strategic plans, the use of social and health impact assessments, as well as more creative inter-disciplinary and bottom-up consultative approaches and working practices.

contentlets.description: Equitable Cities examines contemporary issues facing planners working in a diverse and complex society. Students engage with the broader social, economic and cultural shifts which are continually reshaping the neoliberal city. Students consider questions of spatial disadvantage, social exclusion, ‘spatial justice’ and equity, and ‘rights to the city’. Change in the built environment invariably impacts on disadvantaged and disenfranchised groups disproportionately, where for example redevelopment and gentrification may be accompanied by quickly changing community profiles, rising housing costs, unhealthy environments and potential displacement. As planners we must steward the future direction of our cities and communities in ways which value and foster diversity. Planners must ensure that the interests and needs of all groups, including ethnic communities, children, the aged, women, people with disabilities, people of all sexual preferences, Indigenous and homeless people are heard. Planners are also increasingly engaged with the creation of healthy built environments, fostering wellbeing alongside health professionals in decisions taken which affect the built environment's ability to be supportive of healthy behaviour. The role and capacity of current planning frameworks to achieve more equitable and health supportive outcomes are explored, including the preparation of community strategic plans, the use of social and health impact assessments, as well as more creative inter-disciplinary and bottom-up consultative approaches and working practices.

PLAN2005 Planning Law and Administration introduces students to the legal system and environmental planning law with particular reference to the Australian experience. The course targets three main foci: planning law, planning administration and land/real property. Planning law and Administration considers historical and theoretical issues in law and jurisprudence. This includes engagement with Indigenous land rights, native title and association with land and water management. The administrative context within which planning operates as a function of government is addressed, principally the role and function of statutory bodies in the planning and environment area. The property dimension covers fundamental issues of property rights, property law, methods of valuation, and compensation and betterment.

This assessment consists of a series of in-class tests conducted throughout the semester. 


Written feedback from lecturer

This group assessment consists of a Case Note, explaining a significant case from the Land and Environment Court of NSW, to be presented in class.

 

Written feedback from lecturer

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"583d957fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"943d957fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"983d957fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d43d957fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"483d957fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Planning Law Major Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The major assignment for Planning Law and Administration consists of an 1800-2000 word essay from a choice of several questions covering the full syllabus of the subject.

(Topic Areas include: Statutory Law, Administrative Law and Planning, Property and Land Tenure, Environmental Law, EP&A Act and the Planning System Reform).

 

 

 

Written feedback from lecturer

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN2006","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN2006 - Urban Management and Development Assessment","description":"



This course introduces students to the implementation of planning objectives via the statutory development control system, with particular reference to the NSW planning system. Various development control systems are examined, based on common law, statute and policy. Considered in detail are aspects of statutory and policy planning including the nature of environmental planning instruments, the development application process, and statutory-based development assessment. Emphasis is placed on familiarising students with the practical and creative skills required by a professional planner in undertaking various tasks involved in the development assessment process.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d13139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961935","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essey/Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The development assessment report will address fundamental aspects of the statutory rules, regulations and processes shaping plan making processes and development control decisions. Knowing  DCPs from LEPs is integral to this. Students will prepare a development assessment report focusing on a case study of their choice in the Sydney Metropolitan Area.

The student will be provided with written feedback from the lecturer.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"013139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5d3139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"993139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c13139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d53139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0d3139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a96190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Workshop exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

4 in class exercises (10% each)

The workshop exercises comprise a series of individual and group tasks designed to equip the student with various foundational and disciplinary skills and knowledge required for professional practice.

The workshops will address key concepts discussed in lectures and tutorials. Areas of focus include development processes and assessment, State Environmental Planning Policies (SEPPS), Local Environmental Plans (LEPs), Development Control Plans (DCPs) and the relationship between such planning instruments and urban management. 

The student will be provided with written feedback from the lecturer.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"013139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5d3139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"993139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c13139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d53139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"453139b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In-class test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

In class test will be an individual designed to determine whether students have gained a competent understanding of the NSW Planning System and associated legislation that governs land-use decisions, development and management. Tests will cover topic areas including land use management, development assessment and processes and  the roles and duties of local government planners.

The student will be provided with written feedback from the lecturer

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN2007","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN2007 - City Building: Transport and Infrastructure","description":"

The nexus between transport and land use planning has been a longstanding focus of interest for city planners, in terms of understanding patterns of mobility, determining the need for appropriate transport infrastructure ensuring planning frameworks optimise the benefits to both local communities and the wider city of transport and other infrastructure networks and future investment.


In recent years, interest in maximising the strategic synergies between infrastructure expenditure and urban growth, development and renewal has become increasingly framed by the notion of 'city building'. The reassertion of strategic planning interests in the role that urban infrastructure projects play in 'city building' are acting to reposition the role of the planner, and demand a range of skills that help tie these large financial (and political) commitments more coherently to considerations of city productivity, efficiency, sustainability, and equity.


This course introduces students to the centrality of transport infrastructure considerations both within strategic and statutory contexts. The ongoing pipeline of major transport infrastructure projects in Australian cities offer an excellent lens through which to consider the increasingly integrative role planners play in key city shaping activities which have social, economic and environmental as much as mobility outcomes.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"633512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The aim of this assignment is for students to develop understanding of the relationship between transport, infrastructure provision, urban form, and urban sustainability and to create awareness of considerations surrounding infrastructure development, transport policies, and economics. For this assignment, students are encouraged to play the roles and responsibilities of city planner by exploring and assessing a selected Integrated Transport and Land use project to identify issues and challenges in current land use, transport infrastructure, and integration of these two. Students are expected to analyse opportunities to improve urban liveability by proposing improvement plans of existing land use and transport infrastructure integration and services to improve the sustainability and liveability of the selected case study area. A written feedback will be given.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"633512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6b3512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6b3512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"373552c9dbadf810be4672f5f396192b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Literature review and essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment is designed for students to develop critical skills to analyse transport justification and infrastructure provision by exploring the nexus between transport and land use, key transport concepts relating to infrastructure provision, and methods of infrastructure delivery. Students will review selected scholarly literature presenting various issues related to transport infrastructure planning. Students are expected to submit a short summary and a brief critical analysis of each of the readings and to write a cohesive summary. A written feedback will be given.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"633512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6b3512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6b3512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ab3552c9dbadf810be4672f5f3961926","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Tutorial assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Effective engagement with infrastructure planning issues requires understanding of a number of key concepts and methods. This tutorial assignments will ensure that these building blocks have been engaged with and understood clearly by students. Three individual assignments (each assignment weights 10%) and a written feedback will be given.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"633512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"633512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6b3512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6b3512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"eb3512c9dbadf810be4672f5f39619f9","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PLAN2007.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN2122","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN2122 - History, Heritage and the Built Environment","description":"

This course is an overview of urban planning practice through the framework of important achievements, writings and historical research. The emphasis is on New South Wales and Sydney, and on the 20th century Australian experience. within the contemporary context of global urbanisation. It has three main foci.


First - the evolution of modern planning methods and practice, and the development of urban planning as a distinct profession.


Second - the importance of historical research as an aid to understanding how cities have grown and changed over time – with history providing the intellectual framework for acquiring and storing knowledge..


Third - the changing tools used by planning professionals to assess and protect items of ‘heritage’ in our cities.


Topics include the evolution of models and theories of city planning wjhich have influenced urban planning and urban development in Australian, with some sidelong references to cities in other global locations; city typologies, past and present; ‘ideal’ models of city form; regional and national influences; the evolution of urban government and governance; the modern nation-state and planning; the particular case of Sydney; Adelaide and Canberra as special cases; tools, institutions and practices relating to heritage conservation in New South Wales.

This assessment is a timed online quiz in the Moodle platform that will be comprised of multiple-choice
questions. The quiz will test your knowledge and understanding of course content presented in weeks, 1, 2,
and 3.

Feedback via marking sheet.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2df764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f396190a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Major essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment will require you to prepare a 3500 word essay that composes a critical examination and
insightful well researched and referenced response to one of the questions provided.  

Feedback via analytical rubric.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2df764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2df764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2df764b8db29b810be4672f5f396190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment will require you to prepare an annotated bibliography that provides a well-researched
overview of the published material on a selected topic. The preparation of the annotated bibliography will
include an introduction to the selected topic and an annotated list of references. I suggest that you choose a
topic that is linked to the major essay, that way you will be well-prepared for the essay having reviewed the
body of available literature.

Feedback via rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"25f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2df764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"39f764b8db29b810be4672f5f3961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Case Study ","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

The case study assessment will require you to select a ‘planning era’ (eg colonial 1788-1860, or a major event from the history of planning, or an example of a specific model of planning practice, or the work of a key organization/individual that is significant in the history of planning, urban history or heritage).

Feedback via analytical rubric.

First - the evolution of modern planning methods and practice, and the development of urban planning as a distinct profession.

Second - the importance of historical research as an aid to understanding how cities have grown and changed over time – with history providing the intellectual framework for acquiring and storing knowledge..

Third - the changing tools used by planning professionals to assess and protect items of ‘heritage’ in our cities.

Topics include the evolution of models and theories of city planning wjhich have influenced urban planning and urban development in Australian, with some sidelong references to cities in other global locations; city typologies, past and present; ‘ideal’ models of city form; regional and national influences; the evolution of urban government and governance; the modern nation-state and planning; the particular case of Sydney; Adelaide and Canberra as special cases; tools, institutions and practices relating to heritage conservation in New South Wales.
contentlets.title: History, Heritage and the Built Environment

In an increasingly complex and interconnected world, planning professionals must be able to generate new knowledge and apply it in policy making, planning and implementation processes. Engaging a wide range of communities and stakeholders and tapping into both their experience of cities and their tacit knowledge is central to this task. Planners need to understand the importance of engagement and be able to design community and stakeholder engagement processes and apply appropriate and emerging engagement techniques. During their Practice Year, all students will have the opportunity to develop and enhance their communication and community engagement skills, relevant to government agencies, the general public, local councils, private developers and other built environment stakeholders. Students will draw upon their own experiences to appreciate and reflect upon the centrality of effective communication in engagement.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b2bb333edb41285055a93324f3961900","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Stakeholder assessment matrix ","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment involves in-class project work which leads to an initial presentation at the end of the first intensive session and a follow-up written component. Assuming the position of the proponent, students critically evaluate the stakeholders and community against their potential impacts and/or areas of interest and level of influence over the project. Using the IAP2 spectrum, stakeholders are assigned their level of participation, how they should/need to be engaged and students identify who is best placed to lead the engagement. Each group presents on their stakeholder assessment in-class at the end of the first intensive session, followed by a written component which: provides an understanding of the selected case study, a rationale for the stakeholder groups chosen, or left out (and why) and a summary stakeholder assessment presented as a table, excel document or other.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7ebbb33edb41285055a93324f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7ebbb33edb41285055a93324f396193f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"36bbb33edb41285055a93324f3961942","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Critical Reflection Portfolio ","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Stakeholder and community engagement is an integral and essential part of strategic and statutory planning. Effective communication is also an integral part of organisational behaviours and internal work practices. During your practice year, you should have been exposed to good (and bad) examples of stakeholder and/or community consultation. This assessment expects students to critically reflect on their own experience during their Practice Year to understand how they have interacted with issues of engagement and participation. Portfolios have an advised length of 2000-2500 words, and are individually assessed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"76bbb33edb41285055a93324f396193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7ebbb33edb41285055a93324f396193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7ebbb33edb41285055a93324f396193f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"83bbb33edb41285055a93324f3961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Stakeholder and Community Engagement Strategy ","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Preparation of a stakeholder and community engagement strategy. Drawing upon the outputs of Assignment 1, students will develop a strategy incorporating sections on communication methods, roles and responsibilities, challenges and risks, stakeholders, reporting and evaluation, and engagement.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"76bbb33edb41285055a93324f396193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7ebbb33edb41285055a93324f396193f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8fbbb33edb41285055a93324f3961947","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PLAN3001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Building and using evidence from primary and secondary sources is crucial to strategic planning, effective decision making, assessment, and monitoring and evaluation. Planners are required to confidently utilise data, engage in research and use resulting information across a breadth of tasks and activities tied to their role. This course builds upon the introduction to planning techniques and analysis in PLAN1006 and PLAN2002 to develop a further strengthening of understanding and application of those skills through the lens of live projects, issues and tasks carried out during their Practice Year. Students are expected to build up a portfolio of practice-based projects that demonstrates a deepening of skills and techniques and critical engagement with the evidence-making process reflective of their specific placement contexts. Students will develop a variety of enhanced skills, for example in census or housing market analysis, using 'smart' data, preparing and administering surveys, engaging in qualitative techniques, or manipulating spatial datasets through GIS, city analytics and visualisation. The diversity of students' practice-based learning will be brought together and structured around a series of intensive class periods across the year.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"14003776dbcd6450be4672f5f3961914","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Individual evidence project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Participate in online discussions and intensive classes to support preparation of an individual assignment which draws upon professional practice experiences of the student, and relate these to their planning studies.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"10007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"18007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1c007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"10007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group evidence project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The presentation will take place in the middle intensive teaching session. The class will be fully briefed on this task.
This assessment is in the form of a short debate about a particular topic. For those not familiar with
debating, the ‘topic’ comes in the form of a statement, or assertion, that you either argue for (agree with)
or argue against (disagree with). You will select your topic and side (or for against) at the January intensive
session.

\n

Assessment: You will be working in groups of 5. Team members will get the same mark. You will be
assessed on:
* how well you found, interpreted and presented evidence to support your side of the debate (effectively the content of your first 5 minutes);
* how well you understood and responded to the evidence from the other side of the debate (effectively the content of you last 3 minutes); and
* how clear and persuasive your argument is (not just your presentation skills, but how well you construct your argument – which all team members can help with).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"10007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"18007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"18007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1c007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"14007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619db","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Critical reflections portfolio (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The portfolio provides an excellent opportunity to reflect upon the evidence building process and how it is used. As per instructions for the portfolio across other Practice courses, the format of entries is intended to be flexible. Arguably this is all the more so in PLAN3002 where examples of developing evidence and utilising that evidence can take myriad forms. While many of you will no doubt be crunching some numbers and interpreting figures at some point in the year, some will also be given the opportunity to build knowledge and skills sets in visual/digital data, develop and practice qualitative research techniques, spatial analysis and so on. As such, the potential for innovation and creativity is high.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"10007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"18007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"18007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1c007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"14007776dbcd6450be4672f5f39619dc","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PLAN3002.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: planning and urban development,research skills,using spatial datasets,qualitative research,quantitative research,analysis,gis,evidence base,practice
contentlets.description: Building and using evidence from primary and secondary sources is crucial to strategic planning, effective decision making, assessment, and monitoring and evaluation. Planners are required to confidently utilise data, engage in research and use resulting information across a breadth of tasks and activities tied to their role. This course builds upon the introduction to planning techniques and analysis in PLAN1006 and PLAN2002 to develop a further strengthening of understanding and application of those skills through the lens of live projects, issues and tasks carried out during their Practice Year. Students are expected to build up a portfolio of practice-based projects that demonstrates a deepening of skills and techniques and critical engagement with the evidence-making process reflective of their specific placement contexts. Students will develop a variety of enhanced skills, for example in census or housing market analysis, using 'smart' data, preparing and administering surveys, engaging in qualitative techniques, or manipulating spatial datasets through GIS, city analytics and visualisation. The diversity of students' practice-based learning will be brought together and structured around a series of intensive class periods across the year.
contentlets.title: Practice: Building, Using Evidence

During the Practice Year professional procedures and practice come to the fore, and students are encouraged to think more critically of planning (particularly as a function of the State) and their role as practitioners. This Practice course is intended to accommodate a real-world appreciation of the social, economic, ideological and political context of professional planning. Students will draw upon their own experiences from the practice year to appreciate and reflect upon fundamentals of practice in terms of politics, ethical standards, negligence and workplace psychology, as well as basic tasks faced during their practice year (such as project management and writing/responding to briefs). Students will also be encouraged to discuss the current position of the planning profession, in the broadest setting, of these concepts and practices.

The work-based Critical Reflections Portfolio covers all topics in the Course, with a recommended Table of Contents to be provided. The Portfolio should address each of these matters, reflecting on the practical work experience year. Individually assessed.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN3004","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"3 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN3004 - Practice: Development","description":"

This Practice course is intended to provide students with a framework for critically reflecting upon and developing their understanding of the planner’s role in the process of urban development. Reflecting the breadth of different tasks and projects students may encounter during the Practice Year, the range of case studies that students will draw upon will be equally wide-ranging. For some, engagement with development processes may be primarily at the strategic level; others it may be direct involvement in development assessment and decision-making processes tied to a range of projects; others may be working directly with and for the development industry. In all cases, Practice provides the opportunity to draw together and critically reflect upon the processes at play and the often challenging frameworks within decisions get made.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c573110bdb45285055a93324f39619ce","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Critical reflections portfolio ","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The student must prepare a portfolio which is a critical reflection about what they experienced in the workplace, and the how in their role as planners they observed that they can impact positively or negatively on development outcomes.The key elements the students are asked to reflect on are situations where they (either directly or through association): were presented with a situation where planning controls did not necessarily produce the best outcome;had to determine if something was a good outcome; had to determine if something was in the public interest; needed to take a view on competing interest and/or impacts; had to advise a client / proponent on the approach to take to solve a problem / resolve an issue; needed to consider how the decision being made would impact on the feasibility of a development. Portfolios have an advised length of 2000 (and no more than 2500) words. 

\n

 

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c173110bdb45285055a93324f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c173110bdb45285055a93324f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c573110bdb45285055a93324f39619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c973110bdb45285055a93324f39619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4173110bdb45285055a93324f39619f0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Understanding and evaluating site development ","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a staged assessment task. The first stage involves a multiple choice and short answer test that evaluates comprehension undertaken by the student at the end of Day 1 of the January intensive. Building upon this understanding, the second involves selecting a current development site and providing planning advice on the development outcomes against the site's constraints. Collectively, the task evaluates the student’s ability to consider and balance the competing priorities that shape the development process. Marks and feedback will be provided via MOODLE within 14 days of final submission. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c173110bdb45285055a93324f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c173110bdb45285055a93324f39619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c573110bdb45285055a93324f39619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c973110bdb45285055a93324f39619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8573110bdb45285055a93324f39619ea","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Planning Panel ","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Students participate in a ‘mock’ Planning Panel task. The students are provided with real life contentious projects that were recommended for refusal at a Sydney Planning Panel. In groups of 4-5, the students are allocated to either take the position of Council or the Consultant Planner on the project and present to the Panel why it should or should not be approved based on the planning contentions. The task evaluates the student’s ability to quickly understand and then articulate and argue planning issues. Feedback is provided in the session to the groups after their presentations, in the form of a ‘decision’ of the panel, which also includes members of the class who are not directly involved in that project and can also ask questions of their fellow class mates.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c173110bdb45285055a93324f39619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c573110bdb45285055a93324f39619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c973110bdb45285055a93324f39619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c973110bdb45285055a93324f39619d3","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PLAN3004.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN3005","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"3 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN3005 - Practice: Governance and Policy","description":"

Planners operate within a complex and often highly contested arena. In Practice, students will quickly build awareness of the complexity of the policy process – both in terms of development and implementation – and in the critical role that governance issues play in shaping decision-making and outcomes. In this course students will reflect upon academic debate regarding the institutional frameworks and actors involved in policy making and implementation, and bring into the classroom real world examples from their respective experiences in practice. The course encourages students to critically reflect on the nature in which policy decisions get made, are enacted, how they impact upon planning activity and to help understand how and why decisions get made in the way that they do, or how we assess whether those policies succeed or not through monitoring and evaluation. Drawing upon the cohort’s diversity of Practice experience, the course builds an appreciation of the actors and arenas, methods and institutions contributing to urban management and development so that students are able to engage with such processes effectively in professional life and be aware of the limitations and challenges that inevitable frame activity.   

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"56247b3adbcd6450be4672f5f39619f2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Online and intensive class learning activities ","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

There will be three online learning activities during the year:

  • A forum discussion in March (300 words)

All planners deal with policies in some form or another in their role. In this discussion, students will share a couple of examples where they have interacted with policies at work as introduced in the January class. In a forum with prompts from the moderator, the discussion will focus on how they have used the policy, what they noticed about its design and use, thoughts on why the policy works, and on where there might be risks or failings in it.

  • A quiz in July (30 minute online seminar and 10 multiple choice questions)

The seminar will explore the issues and debates of a contemporary policy issue in urban planning in NSW (e.g housing, public spaces, infrastructure planning etc.). The quiz will use this material as a basis for the questions, focusing on policy processes and techniques discussed in the May class.

  • A blog post in October (500 words)

The blog post requires students to examine a policy issue they have encountered at work and provide analysis and recommendations on improvements to the policy. The post should show a description of a policy problem or failure, describe an objective for a policy solution, and describe an alternative policy framework which may address the problem.

Online feedback will be provided to each acticities throughout the course. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"52247b3adbcd6450be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"66247b3adbcd6450be4672f5f39619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6e247b3adbcd6450be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2624bb3adbcd6450be4672f5f3961904","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"In class group activity","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Reflecting on experiences in the workplace, groups of 4-6 students will work together on a a current planning policy issue representing the breath of stakeholder interests. In its submission, the group will demonstrate an understanding of the stakeholders' interests generally and in the policy issue. By analysing these interests, the group will present a review of the policy issue from a variety of perspectives. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"52247b3adbcd6450be4672f5f39619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"66247b3adbcd6450be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"66247b3adbcd6450be4672f5f39619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6e247b3adbcd6450be4672f5f39619f4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2a24bb3adbcd6450be4672f5f396192b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Critical reflections portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will prepare a portfolio of policy related issues they encounter in work. Building on the concepts, theories, techniques, processes and examples discussed in class, students will make contributions to their portfolio where they use real life work examples to demonstrate a deep understanding of the course content.

Students can choose to use a fewer number of work examples and go into greater analytical depth, or discuss a wider range of examples more briefly. As part of the portfolio, it is anticipated students will synthesise and evaluate the experiences so as to demonstrate a deeper understanding of the key concepts of PLAN3005.

Students will be provided exemplar entries from previous years as a guide, however they are also welcome to use a range of methods e.g. graphs, diagrams, etc., in demonstrating their analytical processes.

Written feedback will be given to the portpolio and discuss in the final class.

contentlets.keywords: planning and urban development,planning
contentlets.description: This course focuses on planning frameworks for the delivery of quality urban outcomes on complex major development sites. The primary aim is for students to acquire a working knowledge and skills for planning and development using techniques of Master Planning. This is an increasingly common technique in planning practice as government and the development industry strive to create more liveable and sustainable communities. The course introduces students to the theory, processes, techniques, and politics of master plans. The focus is more than physical and other aspects covered include social capital, economic appraisal and due diligence. Students workshop the development of a Master Plan for a real world development site. As the third in a series of integrative planning projects, the course enables students to synthesise knowledge and skills acquired in other courses.
contentlets.title: Integrated Planning 3 - Master Planning

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN3052 - Qualitative Methods","description":"

Qualitative Methods focuses on the importance of inter-personal relationship skills in planning practice. The emphasis is on developing and refining such skills to facilitate interviewing techniques for successful qualitative research which underpins humane planning practice. Basic instruction is given in in-depth interviewing techniques - for use in both individual interview situations and focus groups. Students undertake a variety of class exercises to develop their skills in interviewing and rigorous data analysis. A major qualitative research project involves in-depth interviewing, transcription preparation, data analysis, and reporting of findings. Students have the opportunity to reflect on and share experiences. Assessment is based on participation in class discussions and exercises, a major qualitative research project and reading set texts.
