","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN4001","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN4001 - Research Design ","description":"

 


Term 1, Research Design, prepares you to undertake the logical steps of planning the how and why of conducting independent research. You will complete a rigorous ethics application, a literature review, and a final proposal detailing your research design. 


This course focuses on how to do research in planning. It seeks to integrate a range of relevant methodological issues into a foundation for major research investigations—starting with the basics of research design. The approach taken in PLAN4001 is pragmatic and student directed. The course considers fundamental epistemological questions about research paradigms, explores the realities of the research process, and covers practical topics such as doing a literature review, writing and presenting a scholarly piece of work, applying ethical research protocol as per induvial topics, and finally, a review of Harvard referencing. Students gain an understanding of the conceptual, methodological, and technical bases for the construction and timely delivery of research projects. The primary focus of PLAN4001 is to prepare students for the substantive research project in T3 of the BCP student candidature. Lectures, tutorials and assessments guide students towards a developed thesis proposal and plan of study for PLAN4003.


The basic teaching model in PLAN4001 is a series of lectures and small group meetings in class and one-to-one meetings with the Course Lecturers. Class times will generally involve a presentation by the Course Lecturer (2-3 hours) accompanied, where feasible, by a mix of informal discussion/workshop sessions in which students will be actively engaged—sometimes with the class divided into smaller groups appropriate to the timeframe. These components facilitate a degree of learning from your peers (you are all bringing a diverse range of professional experiences to your final year). One-to-one meetings with Course Lecturers assist with individual planning topic queries.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"10271513db4da450be4672f5f396192b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Developed Thesis Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

The final assignment integrates the learning processes and outcomes in the course in the form of a fully-fledged proposal to investigate a specific topic; it is a fuller, more concretised proposal of Assignment 1. You should consider your research proposal with reference to the problem setting, problem statement and objectives, theoretical/conceptual context, implications for policy and/or practice, methodology/operationalization, data sources and an anticipated thesis structure. Each of these headings will need to be discussed separately on one page. Further guidance on the content of the final proposal will be provided in class time.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1c271513db4da450be4672f5f396192b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"18271513db4da450be4672f5f396192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Summary Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

You will prepare a summary research proposal with a working title. The proposal should be no more than two pages. You should consider your research proposal with reference to the problem setting, problem statement and objectives, theoretical/conceptual context, implications for policy and/or practice, methodology/operationalization, data sources and an anticipated thesis structure.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"18271513db4da450be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"18271513db4da450be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"18271513db4da450be4672f5f3961950","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Assignment 2 requires you to undertake a critical review of the relevant scholarly literature - domestic and international - within a subject area of interest to you. This is not a reading diary or brief notes on individual references (annotated bibliography) but a self-contained research report which covers, for an identifiable and manageable topic area, fundamental issues such as the range and depth of contributions, key writers, ‘mapping’ of themes, relevant theoretical approaches and methodologies, findings, questions unanswered/issues for further research etc., as appropriate to the topic being explored.  It is no more than 250 words (excluding references).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"10271513db4da450be4672f5f396192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"18271513db4da450be4672f5f396192c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9c271513db4da450be4672f5f396194c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PLAN4001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN4002","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN4002 - Plan Making Studio","description":"

This course forms the first major component of the “capstone” year of the Bachelor of City Planning (BCP). It involves students applying knowledge and skills acquired in earlier courses, and work experience, to a real-life plan making scenario in Sydney. As with any studio course, the aim is for students to “learn by doing”. Building on the solid foundation provided by the first three years of the BCP degree, the Plan Making Studio course comprises two modules.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f86d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619b8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 - Planning Context and Site Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Initial site investigation and analysis, focused on forming an understanding of the physical and planning conditions which pertain to the site and its surrounds within the urban area at a range of regional and local scales.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f06d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f06d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f46d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f86d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"016d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619c5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3 - Precinct Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students work individually to apply the opportunities and design principles developed in Assessment Two to prepare a comprehensive precinct plan comprising of street hierarchy, walkable blocks, open space network and public transport.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f06d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f06d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f46d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f86d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f86d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"456d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 4 - Stage 1 DA","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

Students work individually to develop an urban design and planning framework for one mixed use block from the previously established precinct plan.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f06d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f06d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f46d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f86d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f86d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b06d52fbdb44f450be4672f5f39619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2 - Analysis, Opportunities and Design Principles","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students respond to the conditions identified in the previous assessment (site investigation and analysis) by formulating a set of opportunities coupled with a robust set of design principles. The opportunities and principles establish a measurable base which guides the subsequent assessment tasks. This assessment also provides an opportunity for critical reflection through iterative review.

contentlets.keywords: planning and urban development,plan-making,planning studio,master planning,urban renewal,urban design
contentlets.description: This course forms the first major component of the “capstone” year of the Bachelor of City Planning (BCP). It involves students applying knowledge and skills acquired in earlier courses, and work experience, to a real-life plan making scenario in Sydney. As with any studio course, the aim is for students to “learn by doing”. Building on the solid foundation provided by the first three years of the BCP degree, the Plan Making Studio course comprises two modules.
contentlets.title: Plan Making Studio

contentlets.keywords: planning and urban development,management skills,research design,independent research,critical analysis,report writing,analytical methods,data acquisition,thesis
contentlets.description: A major research project is the culmination of the undergraduate Bachelor of City Planning (Hons) program. The form of the project is most conventionally a written thesis. The option of incorporating a significant multi-media (e.g. CD-ROM) component may be approved. The thesis project is an individual study taken with the object of allowing students to acquire more specialised knowledge. The range of topics and the methodology is flexible, but a rigorous approach is required. A thesis proposal was developed in the complementary course PLAN4001. While most research, analysis and final preparation may be done off-campus, students are required to maintain close contact with their supervisors throughout the Term 3. There is a minimum requirement of five meetings with individual supervisors in Term 3. In addition to supervisory meetings, students are required to attend course meetings with the convenor and the entire class; the dates for these meetings will be established prior to T3 commencement.
contentlets.title: Planning Thesis

contentlets.keywords: planning and urban development,research design,research methods,planning
contentlets.description: The course consolidates and advances an engagement in research issues in planning studies. It considers key epistemological questions about the nature of research, planning paradigms and methodologies, interdisciplinary perspectives, ethics, pure and applied research needs in planning, and research management. It explores the realities of the research process, covering practical topics such as writing, referencing and presentations. Students gain an understanding of the scholarly and technical apparatus for the construction and delivery of quality research projects. A primary focus is on the substantive research project in the final year of the planning degree. Lectures, guest lectures, tutorials, workshops and continuous assessments guide students toward a developed reach project proposal.
contentlets.title: Research Design

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN4132 - Thesis Project","description":"A major research project is the culmination of the undergraduate planning program. The form of the project is most conventionally a written thesis. The option of incorporating a significant multi-media (e.g. CD-ROM) component may be approved. contentlets.keywords: planning and urban development
contentlets.description: A major research project is the culmination of the undergraduate planning program. The form of the project is most conventionally a written thesis. The option of incorporating a significant multi-media (e.g. CD-ROM) component may be approved. The thesis project is an individual study taken with the object of allowing students to acquire more specialised knowledge. The range of topics and the methodology is flexible, but a rigorous approach is required. A thesis proposal is developed in the complementary course PLAN4031. While most research, analysis and final preparation may be done off-campus, students are required to maintain close contact with their advisers.
contentlets.title: Thesis Project

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"PLAN6000","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN6000 - Planning with Indigenous Peoples","description":"

This course will focus on an appreciation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander knowledge, culture and tradition, specifically as they relate to land and waters. Under the Planning Institute of Australia’s (PIA) Code of Professional Conduct the course will provide a practical understanding of how to engage with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and communities in order to better understand their rights and interests, and especially the importance of their connections to their country and how that may be integrated into contemporary land use and environmental planning. Each week of the lecture will explore these ideas from the viewpoint of the international human rights norms and standards and how the UN Declaration on the rights of indigenous peoples applies to indigenous rights in planning and develop ideas / models of implementation of property rights that may promote equitable, just and culturally relevant economic and social development. Considering the relevance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples’ knowledge and culture to contemporary planning and planning practice, the course will provide a unique opportunity for students to contextualise and interpret Indigenous policy.  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"da0bd45fdba0a01055a93324f39619fc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Workshop and student presentations (1-2 days) with a Sydney Council (e.g. Canterbury Bankstown Council) and respective Local Aboriginal Land Council, on how to best integrate knowledge systems & cultural representation into planning policy and practice in contemporary planning in the LGA.

·             Day 2: Individual Presentation (30%)

o     Part 1: Refining ideas developed on day 1 with feed-back from Council & Local Aboriginal Land Council representatives.

o     Part 2: Students prepare presentation

o     Part 3: Individual presentation to Council & Local Aboriginal Land Council panel via critique.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"120b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1a0b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a0bd45fdba0a01055a93324f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1e0bd45fdba0a01055a93324f39619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"560b185fdba0a01055a93324f396190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Workshop and student presentations (1-2 days) with a Sydney Council (e.g. Canterbury Bankstown Council) and respective Local Aboriginal Land Council, on how to best integrate knowledge systems & cultural representation into planning policy and practice in contemporary planning in the LGA.
 

·             Day 1: Group Presentation (30%)

o     Part 1: Seminar from Council planners and Local Aboriginal Land Council

o     Part 2: Knowledge exchange discussion with representatives from Council & Local Aboriginal Land Council

 

o     Part 3: In groups, students will present the ideas developed, integrating indigenous knowledge systems into planning policy & practice. A panel consisting of Council members will assess and critique the students. This group presentation will inform the individual presentation, with the end goal of presenting to Council & Local Aboriginal Land Council on Day 2

Each week of the course, students will prepare a 3-5 minute podcast discussion. The podcast is a reflection on the lecture content and readings of a specific week.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"120b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1a0b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a0bd45fdba0a01055a93324f39619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9e0b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961901","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

This task will require students to produce a weekly journal on their learnings and reflections. A combination of text, drawings, diagrams, and images is recommended. Students will be marked on completeness, content, and communication.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PLAN6000","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN6000 - Planning with Indigenous Peoples","description":"

This course will focus on an appreciation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander knowledge, culture and tradition, specifically as they relate to land and waters. Under the Planning Institute of Australia’s (PIA) Code of Professional Conduct the course will provide a practical understanding of how to engage with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and communities in order to better understand their rights and interests, and especially the importance of their connections to their country and how that may be integrated into contemporary land use and environmental planning. Each week of the lecture will explore these ideas from the viewpoint of the international human rights norms and standards and how the UN Declaration on the rights of indigenous peoples applies to indigenous rights in planning and develop ideas / models of implementation of property rights that may promote equitable, just and culturally relevant economic and social development. Considering the relevance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples’ knowledge and culture to contemporary planning and planning practice, the course will provide a unique opportunity for students to contextualise and interpret Indigenous policy.  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"da0bd45fdba0a01055a93324f39619fc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Workshop and student presentations (1-2 days) with a Sydney Council (e.g. Canterbury Bankstown Council) and respective Local Aboriginal Land Council, on how to best integrate knowledge systems & cultural representation into planning policy and practice in contemporary planning in the LGA.

·             Day 2: Individual Presentation (30%)

o     Part 1: Refining ideas developed on day 1 with feed-back from Council & Local Aboriginal Land Council representatives.

o     Part 2: Students prepare presentation

o     Part 3: Individual presentation to Council & Local Aboriginal Land Council panel via critique.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"120b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1a0b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a0bd45fdba0a01055a93324f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1e0bd45fdba0a01055a93324f39619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"560b185fdba0a01055a93324f396190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Workshop and student presentations (1-2 days) with a Sydney Council (e.g. Canterbury Bankstown Council) and respective Local Aboriginal Land Council, on how to best integrate knowledge systems & cultural representation into planning policy and practice in contemporary planning in the LGA.
 

·             Day 1: Group Presentation (30%)

o     Part 1: Seminar from Council planners and Local Aboriginal Land Council

o     Part 2: Knowledge exchange discussion with representatives from Council & Local Aboriginal Land Council

 

o     Part 3: In groups, students will present the ideas developed, integrating indigenous knowledge systems into planning policy & practice. A panel consisting of Council members will assess and critique the students. This group presentation will inform the individual presentation, with the end goal of presenting to Council & Local Aboriginal Land Council on Day 2

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"120b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1a0b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a0bd45fdba0a01055a93324f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1e0bd45fdba0a01055a93324f39619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9a0b185fdba0a01055a93324f3961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Podcast","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Each week of the course, students will prepare a 3-5 minute podcast discussion. The podcast is a reflection on the lecture content and readings of a specific week.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PLAN7140","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7140 - Land & Environment Law","description":"

This course seeks to provide an overview of the legal system and environmental planning law with particular reference to the Australian experience. The course targets three main foci: planning law, planning administration and land/real property. Planning law considers historical, theoretical and administrative issues in law and jurisprudence, focusing on the NSW Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 and recent attempts by the Government to overhaul the Planning System. The administrative context within which planning operates as a function of government is addressed, principally looking at the role and function of statutory bodies in the planning and environment area. The property dimension covers fundamental issues of property rights, definitions of value, methods of valuation, and compensation and betterment. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fc387b22db5f6410fe4b322af496193d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group Workshop exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students work in teams to address several hypothetical planning and development scenarios from a legal perspective, gaining practical experience working with LEPs, DCPs and other relevant statutory and policy documents.

 

Written feedback from lecturer is provided to students; marks involve a combination of individual contribution (20%) and group contribution (10%). 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f4387b22db5f6410fe4b322af4961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f8387b22db5f6410fe4b322af496193f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"49387b22db5f6410fe4b322af4961959","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Online quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Multiple choice quiz via Moodle on key introductory concepts from the first three weeks of the course, which set out foundational principles of the legal system and planning law.  

Marks provided via Moodle, with explanations provided of correct responses; students can consult with lecturer for additional feedback if required. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f4387b22db5f6410fe4b322af4961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f4387b22db5f6410fe4b322af4961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"fc387b22db5f6410fe4b322af4961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fc387b22db5f6410fe4b322af4961942","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"74387b22db5f6410fe4b322af4961944","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Major Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students choose one from a list of pertinent planning and environmental questions, and respond in the form of a ~2,000 word essay.

 

Written feedback from lecturer is provided to students.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PLAN7141","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7141 - Land Use Policy & Practice","description":"

Land Use Planning and Practice introduces students to how planning systems are structured and operate, engaging with the institutional frameworks and processes behind the delivery of land use decisions and outcomes. This course aims to introduce students to the administrative and governance contexts within which land use planning operates as a function of government – a function which has become increasingly complex and arguably less coherent within the neoliberal political economy of Australian states and most advanced economies internationally. Clear synergies between strategic and statutory functions are illustrated throughout the course; however, the focus is on the design and implementation of the planning system at State, regional and local scales with particular reference to NSW. Through this lens, students are introduced to statutory and regulatory frameworks and procedures which shape plan making processes, urban management activity and development assessment decisions. As well as exploring how policy is formulated that exercised through a variety of instruments and plans the course places emphasis on the political and practical realities which impact upon institutional settings and their capacity to apply fair and transparent land use decisions. Ongoing questions of Planning reform and how the performance and outcomes delivered by current processes and systems are also discussed.  While the course is necessarily grounded in the NSW context, international perspectives and comparative studies will be discussed throughout. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dd3dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961991","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report: Decision Making.","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

By the end of the course, students will be expected to feel comfortable with the fundamental aspects of the statutory rules, regulations and processes shaping plan making processes and development control decisions. Knowing the distinction between DCPs and LEPs is integral to this task. Several case study localities/situations will be suggested, from which students will be able to select one to write a report about.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"093dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"0d3dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"453dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"813dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c93dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"cd3dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"343dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961959","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class discussion and engagement","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Contribution to discussion and debate in the classroom is actively encouraged.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"093dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"0d3dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961981","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"453dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"813dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c93dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"cd3dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7c3dd57fdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"How We Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This written assessment task (2000 words) will focus on content and debate covered in the first part of the semester, where the broad principles and influences shaping the planning system are discussed. The assignment will enable students to critically engage with the role and positioning of planning – and planners – in land use decisions and wider government social, economic and environmental concerns. Students will be expected to demonstrate an understanding of the governance arrangements, institutional contexts and statutory frameworks within which planners operate. Students will make use of both academic literature and ‘applied’ case study examples to explore their selected question.

City equity and wellbeing explores contemporary issues facing planners working in an increasingly diverse and complex society. Interests in social and community planning infuse multiple scales, and we focus in particular on the metropolitan and local scale. At the wider city scale, students are encouraged to critically engage with the broader social, economic and cultural shifts which are continually reshaping the neoliberal city and consider questions of spatial disadvantage, social exclusion, ‘spatial justice’ and equity and ‘rights to the city’. Change in the built environment often impacts on disadvantaged and disenfranchised groups disproportionately, where for example redevelopment and gentrification may be accompanied by quickly changing community profiles, rising housing costs and potential displacement. As planners we must steward the future direction of our cities and communities in ways which value and foster diversity, and ensure that the interests and needs of all groups, including ethnic communities, children, the aged, women, people with disabilities, LGBT, indigenous and homeless people are heard. Proactively, we are also interested in creating healthy built environments, and fostering wellbeing in decisions taken which affect the built environment. The role and capacity of current planning frameworks to achieve more equitable outcomes are explored, including the preparation of community strategic plans, the use of social impact assessment as well as more creative inter-disciplinary and bottom-up approaches. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"41b1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961984","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

There will be four in-class quizzes (they are held in class time). Each is worth 10% of your total course mark.

i. What is Diversity? What are the challenges?
This in-class assessment will engage with student ideas of equity and diversity.

ii. Equity Quiz
This in-class assessment will engage with material covered in Weeks 1-2.

iii. Health Supportive Cities Quiz
This in-class assessment will engage with material covered in Weeks 3-4.

iv. Field Trip Audit and Quiz
This assignment will be completed in the field and will focus on observations of the built environment using an audit template. FURTHER DETAILS PROVIDED SEPARATELY

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"09b1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"41b1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8db1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c9b1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70b1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961956","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Planning for Inclusion and Equity Symposium – presentation and report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment involves students working intensively, cooperatively and interactively in groups which will be set up early in the Trimester. There are three components to the Symposium: determination of interdisciplinary groups and topics; verbal presentation; submission of presentation slides and commentary / notes. This project is the centre piece of this post graduate course. Working together as a mock ‘consultant’ team, students will prepare and present a well-considered social planning approach for a disadvantaged societal group focusing on equity, inclusion and spatial justice. This will require an in-depth understanding of the needs of the selected group, as well as an appreciation of a comprehensive social planning approach that synergises with sustainability issues more broadly (including economic and environmental sustainability).

Current debates in social planning will form a foundation building block for the approach, as will an appreciation of relevant urban planning theory on equity and social inclusion.

FURTHER DETAILS PROVIDED SEPARATELY

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"09b1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"41b1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8db1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c9b1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b8b1657bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Social Impact Assessment scoping paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Social and health impact assessment applies available research, data and professional assessment to a particular proposal. This assignment requires the identification of a contemporary urban planning issue, project or policy development and preparation of a briefing report to make the case for requirement of an SIA / HIA. Without pre-empting the findings of any impact assessment, the briefing paper will identify the key issues, data sources and proposed methodology for undertaking the impact assessment.

FURTHER DETAILS PROVIDED SEPARATELY

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PLAN7143","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7143 - Urban Design","description":"

Urban design as a field of activity is concerned with the four-dimensional form and functioning of the public realm. It is both a process and a product and is often regarded as the integrative force that straddles and connects the more traditional built environment disciplines: urban design aims to reunite the partnership between planning and design to help improve the quality and sustainability of the built environment. This course provides an introduction to urban design concepts and methodologies in relation to current planning practice. Starting from an appreciation of the fundamentals of design, topics include site investigations, defining urban structure, enhancing the public realm, understanding building typologies, and controlling built form. Specific aims of the course include developing an awareness of the scope of urban design projects, an appreciation of the physical structure of places, an understanding of shaping built form, a familiarity with a range of building typologies, and an appreciation of current urban design issues and debates. Particular skills to be reviewed include site analysis methodology, establishing robust planning and design principles, mapping and spatial understanding, design review criteria and mechanisms of development control.

Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PLAN7144","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7144 - Planning History, Theory and Culture","description":"

‘Planning history has been around as long as planning’, wrote the late British urban historian Anthony Sutcliffe. While urban planning by definition ‘looks to the future’, planners ‘need the past more than anyone, for without it they cannot draw on experience’. This course provides a wide-ranging advanced overview of the development of planning ideas, theory and practice. It is intended to help underpin - and help critically situate – contemporary professional knowledge, approaches and values. The course is organised thematically around a number of broad themes addressing the origins of modern planning thought, key figures and ideas, the evolution of different planning paradigms and cultures through the 20th century, the diffusion and adaptation of planning concepts and policies, and the achievements and shortcomings of planning in practice. The coverage will be global, but orientated to the Anglophone world, and assessment geared to the Australian and Pacific-Rim realms. The course will be structured around synoptic lectures, workshop discussions evaluating primary documentation, and student presentations. Assessment will be based on participation, written assignments, and presentations.

A short written individual assignment on a set topic, such as the historical backdrop to an important planning issue in the news. 


Written feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5c37433dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fdc37433dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"29c37433dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thematic presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Individual presentation leading or co-leading the introduction to group discussion of a thematic issue. 


Peer discussion, written feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"35c37433dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"42c37433dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f5c37433dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fdc37433dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"29c37433dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Engaging with planning, and planners in practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

An oral history interview with an experienced planning figure (professional, commentator, community) on their engagement with planning in practice (could be built around one major project or class of projects) capturing their education, influences, experiences, institutional and political setting, and assessment of outcomes. This will be accompanied by an interpretative essay of 2500 words, and can be undertaken individually or within a small team. There will be an accompanying presentation towards the end of semester. 


Consultation, peer discussion, written feedback.

The nexus between transport and land use has been a longstanding focus of interest for city planners, in terms of understanding patterns of mobility, their combinational impact on city’s sustainability, and determining the need for appropriate transport infrastructure ensuring planning frameworks optimise the benefits to local communities, the wider city transport networks and future investment. In recent years, interest in maximising the strategic synergies between infrastructure expenditure and urban growth and sustainability, development and renewal has become increasingly framed by the notion of 'city building'. The reassertion of strategic planning interests in the role that urban infrastructure projects play in 'city building' are acting to reposition the role of the planner, and demand a range of skills that help tie these large financial (and political) commitments more coherently to considerations of city sustainability, productivity, efficiency and equity. This course introduces students to the centrality of transport and infrastructure considerations both within strategic and statutory contexts. The ongoing pipeline of major transport infrastructure projects in Australian cities offer an excellent lens through which to consider the increasingly integrative role planners play in key city shaping activities which have social, economic and environmental as much as mobility outcomes.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"afb7110edbffa050fe4b322af4961907","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Project report ","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will look at land use planning implications tied to transport infrastructure provision. A range of tasks will be undertaken through application of software such as GIS and/or analytical techniques to demonstrate the understanding of the key concepts including transport and network typologies, travel behaviour and patterns, transport disadvantage and transit oriented development.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a7b7110edbffa050fe4b322af496190b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"afb7110edbffa050fe4b322af4961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"afb7110edbffa050fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a3b7110edbffa050fe4b322af496190f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Literature review and essay ","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will review and critically assess a recent or current NSW’s long-term infrastructure plan. Drawing upon both academic literature and policy frameworks, students will explore various issues and implications arising from the interplay between infrastructure provision and city shaping in the context of a major metropolitan city (2500 words)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a3b7110edbffa050fe4b322af4961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a7b7110edbffa050fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"afb7110edbffa050fe4b322af496190a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a3b7110edbffa050fe4b322af4961911","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Tutorial assignment ","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Effective engagement with infrastructure planning issues requires understanding of a number of key concepts and methods.The tutorial assignment is a combination of ongoing exercises and readings designed to assess engagement with and comprehension of key concepts.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PLAN7146","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7146 - City Economics, Urban Development & Finance","description":"

The course exposes students to economic theory and applies that knowledge to assist the student's appreciation of the economic imperatives which drive and shape urban development.  Interest in this course focuses on both broader spatial-economic considerations which shape our understanding of how the city ‘works’ in terms of competing pressures on land use, concepts of supply and demand, location theory, opportunity costs and marginalism. Insight is drawn from both economics and critical urban theory to explore the role of planning in the context of market operation, considering both efficiency and equity based rationale for potential intervention and what those interventions might and should look like. The second strand of this course looks in detail at the processes involved in land and property development in market economies in the context of government supervision of regulatory and approval processes. Through a range of case studies and drawing upon industry expertise, students are introduced to economic feasibility models to consider development from the perspective of all stakeholders involved, building greater awareness of the risks, costs and considerations shaping process. Topics include the nature and purposes of property development, real property law, development economics, the regulatory context, and taxation issues.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fc48a1bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961918","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Take Home Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The final exam aims to assess your level of understanding of the key themes, concepts, ideas and trends taught in PLAN7146 City Economics, Urban Development and Finance – Term 1, 2020. The exam comprises four sections; multiple choice, diagramming/interpretation, short answer and one extended response. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"244861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"604861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6848a1bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a448a1bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ac4861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e048a1bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"144861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be actively encouraged to participate and engage in class discussions. 

A grade will be provided for the exam and for attendance and participation.

Grade provided in Moodle 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6848a1bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ac4861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5c4861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Essay (1500 words)","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 1: Essay (1500 words) - 30% 

This assessment task is an opportunity to consolidate upon the first three (3) weeks of the course. The objective of this assessment is to demonstrate an understanding of land use theory and spatial structure, the concepts of supply, demand and equilibrium and the role of the public and private sector in urban economic growth and transformation.

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"244861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"604861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6848a1bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ac4861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"804861bbdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Group Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 2: Group Presentation - 30%

The group presentation (Pecha Kucha) is an opportunity to apply your knowledge of key concepts, theories and ideas covered in the first six (6) weeks of term. In completing this task, you will be engaging with, and demonstrating an understanding of some or all of the following: economic concepts and models that help explain land values and the location of economic activity; concepts of supply, demand and equilibrium; the role and function of public and private sector in urban economic growth; the impact of infrastructure provision on land use and spatial structure; and an understanding of social and economic issues.

The Pecha Kucha format will require you and your group to make the complex simple – having only 20 slides of 20 seconds each to communicate your argument, or analyse your topic. The weekly deliverables will help provide a structure for the preparation of your presentation. The fact sheet is an opportunity to clearly communicate your topic for the educational benefit of your peers.

Aims: 

Provide a compelling argument / detailed analysis grounded in evidence-based research in relation to one of the topics below.

Undertaking broad research, utilising valid and reliable sources of information, making the complex simple through an engaging graphic presentation will be key to a successful presentation.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PLAN7147","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7147 - Planning Techniques & Analysis","description":"

There are a number of core skills and techniques that shape the planners' task. An appreciation of the range, utility and meaning of research and analytical techniques is a fundamental part of the planner's methodological training. This course provides an introduction to basic techniques of survey design, data collection and analysis, introductory statistics. Students will learn when to apply particular techniques and how to do so.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0c1c59bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial / lab exercises (individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The tutorial / lab exercises help students develop computing technology-based research skills. Included in the lab will be in-depth, and more importantly, hands-on exposure to software including Excel, NVivo and SPSS. In bringing together the techniques developed, students will undertake an individual research exercise where these newly developed skills can be applied. Weekly lab tasks will be indivisually assessed and marked by a tutor and feedback should be provide in the following week. 

 

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"330c19bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4c1c19bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"881c59bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c41c59bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"230c19bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam (individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Final exam provides further opportunity to assess indivisual understanding of a range of planning technigues and anlaytical skills throughout the course. The exam tests their ability of critical appraisal of information in assessing and evaluating diverse evidence relevant to planning. It will include a variety of short answer, multiple choice questions, data interpretation and short essay questions. The results will be informed via Moodle. 

 

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"001c59bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"330c19bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4c1c19bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"330c19bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual planning report (individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

This report involves the statistical analysis of ‘real’ data sets and will build on the sequence of SPSS exercises undertaken during the lab session.  The written report will comprise a small introductory literature review leading to the development of student research question, a description of the survey and a rationale for the statistical analyses that would most appropriately test the selected research question with the dataset provided by the lecturer.  The report should include a discussion of sampling and ethical issues, a critique of the survey incorporating suggestions for improvements of the survey.  Individual marks and feedback will be provided via Moodle within 10 days.   

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"001c59bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"330c19bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4c1c19bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"881c59bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c41c59bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7b0c19bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Survey Design (individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment is to develop and desgin survey questionnaire on an actual planning-related issue. Students need to search a newspaper article dealing with any planning issue of thier interest, which is presumably controversial or attracts attention from local residents. The assignment consists of the five sections: 

1. Survey design (1,000 ± 100 words)

- Introduction:

? Backgrounds, reasons and significance of the survey

- Survey objective(s):

? What you want to achieve through the survey and what is the focus of the survey

- Sampling design:

? Target population (area coverage)

? Sampling method

? Data collection method

? Sample size

? Time schedule

- Questionnaire design:

? Concept(s) and variables (operationalisation of the key concepts): provision of conceptual and operational definitions

? Structure / composition of the questions

- Ethical considerations

* This documents should be written in full sentence. Please stick to the subheadings.

2. Cover letter (addressed to potential participants): 1 page

- Survey title

- Introduction of the survey project: backgrounds and aims of the survey, significance of the survey

- Introduction of the questionnaire: overview of the questions, instruction for participants how to complete the questionnaire)

- Any Important information that participants need to know before deciding to participate

- Your contacts

* Please refer to the example cover letters on Moodle

3. Questionnaire

- No more than 20 questions in total

- Inclusion of no more than 2 open ended questions

- Inclusion of all levels of measurement (nominal, ordinal, and scale)

- Inclusion of scaled questions

4. Participant Information Statement

- Fill out the template on Moodle

* Please do not change the font

5. Appendix: Newspaper article

- Attach a newspaper article that prompted the survey

Grade and written feedback will be provided in Moodle within 10 days

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PLAN7148","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7148 - Strategic Spatial Planning","description":"

Strategic planning is a dynamic, analytical, and interdisciplinary process. It encapsulates the principal mechanisms whereby planners understand, create, and care for, places and addressing the core challenges and opportunities faced by urban environments and their communities – both existing and future. Strategic spatial planning within the university classroom is where the practical, applied nature of the discipline is critically interrogated through a more conceptual, theoretical and critica lens. The key drivers of change within our cities, for example housing supply and affordability, urban renewal, urban justice, infrastructure and transport, are unpacked, and the tensions that shape how decisions get made – or not – understood through the complex lens of urban governance and how planning – and planners – engaged with those we plan for. As planners we are interested in the inherently spatial dimensions of these urban processes, recognising that collective efforts to influence land use change and behaviours of urban stakeholders take place at different geographical scales, and impact on different groups in different ways.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"733179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written assignment One Strategic spatial planning key principles","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

Written assignment 1:

This assignment requires students to engage with and demonstrate their understanding of the key arguments framing contemporary interest in strategic spatial planning. The academic literature raises a number of complex but invaluable ideas, helping challenge thinking and how they might approach strategic planning issues in a more critical, effective way. Students have the choice of answering the question through the lens of the current metropolitan plan for Greater Sydney, and arguing whether it can be seen as a ‘good’ example of strategic spatial planning? If so, in what ways? If not, why not? Target word length 1700-2000.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"233179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2b3179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6f3179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b3179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a96198c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written assignment two Briefing/primer on strategic planning issue","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Written assignment 2: Briefing/primer on a strategic planning issue

Students prepare a briefing or ‘primer’ where they set out the facts, arguments, debates and key directions to an incoming policy director from a selected list of issues (e.g. urban renewal). They do so by drawing upon evidence, best practice from elsewhere and by using the critical concepts and ideas explored in the academic literature. What are the key issues? Where are the opportunities? The concerns? A good strategic briefing offers an invaluable primer for the Tsar to take forward their thinking. The primer will be accessible in format. Target word length 2000-2500.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"233179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2b3179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"673179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6f3179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"933179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961991","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group presentation Sub-regional/local strategic directions pitch","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Group Assignment: Sub-regional/local strategic directions pitch

In groups of 3-4, students prepare a pitch to help shape the strategic direction for the emerging Western Parkland City. The aim is for students to convince key urban policymakers that what they think is important should be important to them. The goal is to present a compelling argument for an action, project, idea that students think will help deliver the strategic planning directions for the Western Parkland City. The pitch can be about any aspect/issue that will shape this part of Greater Sydney: the aerotropolis, jobs, infrastructure, universities, health infrastructure etc. Creativity in presentation format (no more than 10 minutes per group) is encouraged.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"233179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619b8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2b3179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"673179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"db3179b3db315c50eb6b147a3a961995","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/PLAN7148.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PLAN7149","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7149 - Planning Thesis","description":"

Research is a fundamental underpinning to urban planning both as a discipline and practice, and preparation of a thesis acts as the primary capstone activity for students completing the Master of City Planning degree. It enables students to deepen knowledge in an aspect of planning and urban studies and demonstrate capacity to develop and evaluate arguments, perform critical analysis and synthesis and apply creative thinking to complex problems. The focus of the research is determined by the student, and will normally have been initially developed through the preparation of a research proposal and literature review as part of a preceding faculty research design course, BENV7020. Students are assigned a supervisor, who will offer advice and provide feedback throughout the research process and thesis preparation. Students will usually undertake primary fieldwork, and put into practice core research and analysis skills developed throughout the degree. Preparation of a c15,000 word thesis also build students’ capacity to recognise and demonstrate the importance of coherence, logic, structure, relevance and accuracy in written outputs, presented in a creative and compelling way [edited from UNSW Handbook, 2019].


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f2fb55bbdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final thesis (15,000 words)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

The final thesis provides the major output of this course. Examiners will be looking for strengths and weaknesses in your work. Three key general criteria are (1) quality of project content (originality, initiative and value-add evident) (2) organisation (structure, completeness and comprehensiveness of the final product), and (3) presentation (written and visual communication standards). In more detail, the heads of consideration helping to guide examiners in the examination process are summarised below:

Topic aims and purpose: Clarity of problem setting. Clear and appropriate articulation of a central research question(s) and research objectives. Intellectual and/or policy relevance of the topic. Rigour of conceptualisation of approach to a specific problem(s). Awareness of the strengths and limitations of the approach.

Literature review: Grounding of the research questions in the appropriate Australian and international scholarly literature. Critical review of the relevant empirical, policy and theoretical literature.

Methodology: Adoption and explication of an appropriate and ethical methodology to execute research. Extent of critical thinking and/or primary data collection. Quality of analytical skills demonstrated.

Structure and style: Well-organised, written, presented and referenced thesis. Appropriate figures and tables. Use of correct grammar, spelling and accessible jargon-free prose. All elements complete to guidelines including appropriate length. No evidence of plagiarism.

Findings and significance: Level of understanding demonstrated. Quality of findings reported and veracity of conclusions reached in relation to the research approach. Significance of the findings as an original contribution to knowledge and/or policy. Could this be the basis of a publication?

Students will subsequently be required to submit a final pdf copy which makes any required corrections identified by the markers. This is to enable theses to be published on the Faculty website. Deadline: This final pdf copy must be provided before marks are recorded on transcripts.

The Housing Policy and Finance course will enable students to gain a broad understanding of the operation of Australia's contemporary housing system; the key agencies and their roles; how housing markets function; and the main subsidy, tax policy and regulatory measures that impact on the housing system. Students will become familiar with the key demographic, political, cultural and economic factors shaping housing policy, and with broader perspectives on the policy making process. Framing themes running through the course will include system governance and the distributional consequences of housing systems. With the exception of Indigenous housing, the course remit will be limited to metropolitan Australia. Throughout the course, however, Australian policy frameworks and mechanisms will be considered within an International comparative context. This course will be offered in an intensive mode.

An essay chosen from a list of five questions relating to subjects covered during the first two thirds of the course. Essays are submitted online via turnitin, with marks and marker feedback also provided via turnitin. Essays must refer to academic and policy literature on the chosen topic, as well as referencing the relevant lecture where possible. Essay structure must include an introduction and conclusion, as well as in-text source citation and a reference list at the end in Harvard style.

Essays are submitted online via turnitin, with marks and brief marker feedback also provided via turnitin. Essays must refer to academic and policy literature on the chosen topic, as well as referencing the relevant lecture where possible. Essay must include in-text source citation and a reference list at the end in Harvard style.

These address specified issues relevant to the subject of the session in question. Students work in groups self-chosen or designated by the course leader. Presentations draw on the reading material prescribed for the relevant session. Each group presentation is limited to 15 minutes, with responses to each mandated question being limited to a maximum of 3 powerpoint slides
