Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7157 - Engaging Communities","description":"

Engaging Communities focuses on opportunities and challenges at the heart of 21st century policy and planning issues. The urban practitioner's role has always been instrumental in working through the complexity of a pluralistic society with different opinions, needs, preferences and different levels of power which influence urban change. Addressing these complexities is now the central aim of most government authorities which are seeking new ways of engaging communities - consulting, involving, collaborating and partnering with the general public and stakeholders. This course offers a theoretical underpinning for a very practical approach to designing and delivering public and stakeholder involvement processes. Drawing on contemporary urban policy challenges and reforms, students will be introduced to best practice engagement processes and novel insights into the application of engagement techniques from leading urban policy academics and practitioners and through executive-type peer learning.


This postgraduate elective course provides a theoretical basis for Built Environment postgraduate coursework programs, especially MPLAN and MUPS students.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"799ae2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961930","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"TECHNIQUE: INTERVIEWS. Interviewing your peers [individual]","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Each student will be interviewing three of their class peers, as members of the public. Each interview will be 20 minutes long. Together with your research partner, these interviews will contribute to your overall engagement process. You will need to record these on a phone, tablet or computer to manage and analyse the findings gathered from this technique in the Final Client Report. During the interview you should discuss key issues, the current debate and ask about for your interviewee’s perspective on the hot topic. Your Interview Schedule must be approved by Nancy before we resume class in April.
Grading Criteria:
? Preparation for the interview + Interview Schedule
? Clarity with which material is structured and presented in the interviews
? Style of interviewing

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"319ae2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a99aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e59aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d9aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619ba","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"TECHNIQUE: PUBLIC BRIEFING","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Treat this presentation to the class as a public briefing on your hot topic. In a 10 minute presentation with your team mate, you must present the essence of your topic. Include, but do not be limited to the following questions: What are the key issues? What has been the current debate thus far? Has there been any community consultation on this issue to date? Who are your key stakeholders? Who might be future stakeholders? What will be the impact of your policy-decision/plan? Each of you should present part of this briefing and have some sort of visual aid or PowerPoint presentation to assist you.
Grading Criteria:
? Clarity with which material is structured and presented
? Level of understanding of a complex idea/hot topic
? Quality and communication impact of visual aid and oration

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"319ae2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a99aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e59aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"559aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96198c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"TECHNIQUE: Pecha Kucha 20x20 [individual]","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Each student is required to deliver a work-in-progress talk in the Pecha Kucha format. This new and innovative format for presentations is where you show 20 images and talk to each for 20 seconds. The idea behind this is to focus public presenters quickly. In ~6 ½ minutes supported by graphic images, you must discuss your topic, report findings to date, and reflect on the engagement process and your managing of it to date.
Grading Criteria:
? Comprehension and understanding of the topic presented
? Verbal presentation style, clarity within the Pecha Kucha format
? Graphic presentation of the slides (graphic style, content, relevance to the topic, readability)
? WOW factor?

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7d9ae2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e59aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"659aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"TECHNIQUE: QUESTIONNAIRE. Surveying the general public [individual]","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Each student will be out on the streets to conduct 10 ‘person-on-the-street’ surveys. If you want to do more – feel free up to a max of 15 each. This questionnaire will be a product of working with your research partner and is based on your hot topic. Again, together with your research partner, these combined ~20 surveys will contribute to your overall engagement process. You will need to manage and analyse the findings gathered from this technique in the Final Client Report. Your survey must be approved by Nancy before we resume class in April. It should briefly summarise your hot topic, and ask your respondents for their perspectives on certain aspects of your topic.
Grading Criteria:
? Preparation and expression of the survey
? Clarity, comprehensiveness and structure of the questionnaire
? Style of surveying

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"319ae2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a99aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e59aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9d9aa2e7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961990","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"FINAL CLIENT REPORT Managing the process + presenting your findings [pairs]","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"40","description":"

As mentioned, the class will be given several topical public policy issues and scenarios. With your research partner, each team will manage and triangulate the data collected from 6 peer interviews, numerous Twitter Tweets, 20 public surveys, government statistics, plans, and any other organisational position papers, legislation, policy documents that exist on the topic. Any other findings on your hot topic should be added to this report. This Final Client Report will outline the public involvement techniques you used, their strengths and limitations, the data management process, and the overall findings of the consultation process. The public issue should be described thoroughly; stakeholders identified; and contentious issues within the topic highlighted. An additional handout will be provided in class regarding the details of this major assignment.
Grading Criteria:
? Clarity with which material is structured and presented for the hot topic
? Depth of understanding of the issue and the context of community engagement on the topic
? Reflective discussion on the engagement methods used and your data management processes
? Quality of writing, grammar and graphics

contentlets.keywords: planning and urban development,community engagement,strategic planning,urban policy,deliberative democracy,engagement techniques and tools,stakeholder engagement
contentlets.description:
Engaging Communities focuses on opportunities and challenges at the heart of 21st century policy and planning issues. The urban practitioner's role has always been instrumental in working through the complexity of a pluralistic society with different opinions, needs, preferences and different levels of power which influence urban change. Addressing these complexities is now the central aim of most government authorities which are seeking new ways of engaging communities - consulting, involving, collaborating and partnering with the general public and stakeholders. This course offers a theoretical underpinning for a very practical approach to designing and delivering public and stakeholder involvement processes. Drawing on contemporary urban policy challenges and reforms, students will be introduced to best practice engagement processes and novel insights into the application of engagement techniques from leading urban policy academics and practitioners and through executive-type peer learning.

This postgraduate elective course provides a theoretical basis for Built Environment postgraduate coursework programs, especially MPLAN and MUPS students.
contentlets.title: Engaging Communities

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7320 - Housing Management and Markets","description":"

The Housing Management and Markets course will enable students to gain an understanding of the rental housing and strata management industry. As regards 'housing management' the course will concentrate on 'managed housing'; that is the 'professionally administered' part of the housing market. This will entail a focus on multi-occupied residential buildings (the strata sector), on market rental dwellings under professional real estate management, and on affordable rental housing run by social landlords (primarily state governments and not-for-profit community housing providers). The husbandry of owner occupied housing and mum-and-dad-investor-managed market rental housing will therefore be largely outwith the course remit. Students will learn about 'housing management industry' structure, about rental and strata property law, about the property and tenancy management practice, and about rental property investment practice. They will also become familiar with analytical methods applicable to property investment and market performance. Framing themes running through the course will include business practices and technological developments impacting on the efficiency and effectiveness of housing management practice, as well as on the housing system more broadly. While the coverage will focus primarily on Australian policy frameworks and industry practices, where possible these will be considered within an international comparative context.

Presentations will address questions related to (a) governance of multi-occupied buildings, (b) resident involvement in social and affordable housing, (c) models for management of market rental housing.


Peer critique and marking

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PLAN7321 - Implementing Urban Regeneration Projects","description":"

Implementing urban regeneration projects exposes students to real-world regeneration activity in practice. Historical and recent initiatives, programs and programs will be critically assessed - often drawing upon the expertise of policy makers and practitioners directly involved in their design and delivery - before students focus on a specific project or initiative. Students will explore the realities of evidence-based policy design and development including options appraisal, the roll out of programs from a political, governance and financing perspective, the day-to day-operation of renewal and project management, and the importance of monitoring, evaluation and review. Throughout students will build an understanding of the stakeholders involved, how decisions get made, and who s affected by those decisions. The resulting skills set seeks to encourage students to recognise the importance of creative, strategic thinking in addressing complex urban issues, alongside the need for pragmatic and realistic frameworks for delivering change on the ground.   

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c967fc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96192d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Regeneration in practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This first assignment will draw upon evidence/literature/policy evaluations of urban regeneration activity. The aim will be to encourage students to critically engage with the complexities tied to the regeneration process in practice and appreciate the challenges of translation between initial policy intent and the outcomes achieved. 


The course convenor will provide written feedback to the students 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7067fc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bc67fc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f867fc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6067bc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Designing a regeneration program","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

A challenge, task and parameters for intervention will be established. From this small groups will work up a proposal outlining how a major regeneration policy/program will be operationalised. This will necessarily take into account research and evidence building, options appraisal, governance and financing frameworks, communication and engagement, demonstrating an awareness of likely impact across stakeholders and communities benefiting from/affected by regeneration activity. 


Groups will present to a panel of practitioners. A written component of this group exercise will be marked by the course lecturer and written feedback provided to students 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0967fc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4567fc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"8167fc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bc67fc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96191b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a867bc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

At this level, active participation in class discussion and debate is vital in order to get the most out of the learning experience.  


Ongoing

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4567fc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a867bc7bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Regeneration program delivery","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will develop either a monitoring and evaluation framework, an on-going research program, or a communication and engagement strategy as an integral component of the wider implementation tool kit tied to the delivery of a regeneration program.  


The course lecturer will provide written feedback to the students
